'Lithium aluminium hydride', commonly abbreviated to 'LAH' or known as
'LithAl', is an inorganic compound with the chemical formula LiAlH 4.
It was discovered by Finholt, Bond and Schlesinger in 1947. This compound is used as a reducing agent in organic
synthesis, especially for the reduction of esters, carboxylic acids, and
amides. The solid is dangerously reactive toward water, releasing gaseous
hydrogen (H 2). Some related derivatives have been discussed for
hydrogen storage.
